Beginners to Winners Bridge begins with modified rules to teach the concepts of Bridge, but also includes rules for Contract Bridge with four players.

With the included two-player rules, all 52 cards are dealt out. While both sets of partner cards are face down, both players make their first bid. Once this has been done, each player will set up his partner cards in his partner rack, according to suit. The card racks hold the cards at 45-degree angles, allowing a person to see the cards opposite them, but not their opponent's cards. Each player will play the cards in their partner rack as well as his own cards. The bidding continues as each player studies their partner hand as well as their own. Players can raise the bid until 7 NT is bid or until one player passes.

There is a simplified scoring system for the beginners' game. One point is given for each trick won. Both the Declarer and the Defender can win these points. If the Declarer wins at least the number of tricks called for, they win a bonus of 10 points. If he doesn't, the Defender wins a bonus of 5 points and the Declarer deducts 1 point for each Undertrick. The first player to score 30 points wins the game.

Name: Crown Duels
Description:
Crown Duels is a 2-player card game that uses a standard deck of playing cards and an optional, self-printable playing mat.

The aim of the game is to destroy your opponent’s Nobility (picture cards) before they destroy yours.

Play requires hand management and a variety of simple rock, paper, scissors type comparisons using suits that play-out as a series of skirmishes between foot soldiers, trying to defend their Nobility from attack.

Name: Fox and Hounds Card Game
Description:
44 cards, all showing characters at the fox-hunt; Hounds, Lady Riders, Huntsmen, the Fox and the Whip.
All the cards are dealt to each player. After dealing one card to each player, the dealer must add one to the pool as well so that the game starts with a number of cards in the pool. Each player is given 24 counters. The person holding the Whip card cries "Tally Ho!" and asks the player of his choice if he has the Fox card. Various penalties occur if he is right or wrong. Then the Whip is placed into the pool cards, which are now shuffled.
Now each player asks a player for a card, and if he makes a trick, he can claim it in front of him. Then he takes a number of counters from the pool and adds them to his other counters. If a pair of Hounds is played, he collects 3 counters, a pair of Lady Riders, 6 counters; a pair of huntsmen, 9 counters; a special pair of the Whip and the Fox, 12 counters and that trick counts as two tricks at the end of the game. All cards in the pair must match numbers as well as images.
When all the cards are collected as pairs, the player with the most tricks takes the remaining counters in the pool, and the one with the most counters, wins.

Name: Game of Japan
Description: One of a range of cheaper games in the early 20th century. I have no rules but it looks like a simple roll-and-move game, but the publisher has tied it to an oriental theme, for no reason than the Orient was a popular subject at the time.

Name: Battle of Assaye
Description:
This is a free analog of General Wellesley (later Wellington) and Scindia in India "King"in the great battle, the battle for the decisive battle of the war, later recalled this Wellington His campaign is a campaign to fight the best.
The game includes a map, the operator 9 * 6 plates and a help card, these parts include only the print is free of charge can be used directly.
Fighting is the result obtained by direct roll, no CRT, but not so simple. Including the impact and fire fighting methods, different branches of the military way of fighting have some differences. There are 5 scenario, the victory conditions vary.

Name: Count Your Blessings
Description:
From the Manufacturer:
Object of the game is to be the first player to flip their 4 tokens from "Stressed to Blessed", "Tired to Inspired", "Frazzled to Dazzled", and "Mad to Glad" simply by looking on the positive side of life! Spin the spinner, find the silver lining, and collect cards to come out a winner. Count Your Blessings is all about finding the "bright side" to each scenario on the cards, no matter how big the challenge, and seeing that every situation in life is full of "blessings-in-disguise". The Youngest player goes first by spinning the spinner. The corresponding card is read, a silver lining response is given, and in some cases, voted on. See specific card instructions below. Play continues in a clockwise direction until one player wins the game by turning all 4 tokens over to the sunny yellow side!

Contents:

     1 sun spinner board, 
     215 game cards, 
     24 tokens, 
     6 heads or tails coins, 
     1 pair Look on the Brightside glasses
Families: Books: Chicken Soup for the Soul

Name: Chicken Soup for the Preteen Soul
Description:
Another game from the Chicken Soup series.
Player answer questions about things that are important to preteens in order to collect six "Life's Ingredients" cards (happiness, love, hope, joy, faith, and peace).
Families: Books: Chicken Soup for the Soul

Name: CRY H.A.V.I.C.
Description:
CRY H.A.V.I.C. (Heavy Assault Vessel Infantry Carrier) is a table-top futuristic SF 25 mm miniature game for two or more players.  The game requires miniature figures to represent troops on the battlefield.  Talon Games produced a line of CRY H.A.V.I.C. miniatures.

Set in the 26th century, mighty empires clash for valuable worlds and the resources and power they provide.  Power armor soldiers and intelligent M.A.R.S. (Mobile Assault Robotic Soldiers) units make up the bulk of fighting forces with the H.A.V.I.C. carrying them through space from one battlefield to another.  More than merely armored transports, H.A.V.I.C.s serve a base of operations for its troops.  (From back cover)

The rulebook has been designed to teach the gamer how to play in and to better understand the universe of Cry H.A.V.I.C.  Each area of the rulebook falls under one of four headings.

The Introduction:  This section describes the background of the game's universe and provides details on some of the major events that helped to shape the galaxy as it is in the year 2572.

The Rules: The rules section explains the concepts, techniques and philosophy of the game.  The rule book says that it can accommodate a wide number of units per side but recommends that starting players begins with 5-7 units per side and then add additional troops.

Equipment and Design: This section describes some of the equipment that could be found on the modern battlefield as well as the basic military formations and setup of the two major powers in the game system: The Terran Confederation and The Ryuuza Imperium.

The Universe: This part details some of the many personalities that are found in the Cry H.A.V.I.C. gaming universe.  A short story is also included here.   (From rule book)

It is a 25 mm miniature game which uses d10 for all rolls.  Distances in the game are measured in inches.  Each square inch of the gaming table represents an area 5 feet across.  The turn is 30 seconds long and is broken up into two rounds of 15 seconds.  Each round is made up of four action phases which are used to organize the actions of every unit.

Name: Batteries
Description:
"A game which uses ordinary playing cards in a new and fascinating way" Box blurb 
Cards are played 1 at a time to activate pieces on the board.  Pieces are moved to scoring positions and do battle with opposing pieces by stacking up in a line "battery" and overpowering the opposition.

Name: Quick War
Description: This is a set of rules to play a WWII game with 1:144 miniatures. It doesn't use a lot of look up tables, and is easy to learn. That's why I call it "Quick War". This set of rules uses no game board, instead units are moved by measurements in inches, and rulers are used also for firing weapons. I use different colors of felt to denote hills, forest, water, and roads. Units may be hidden and put on opportunity fire, or be activated to move and fire. There are rules for artillery and infantry as well. Infantry may be used as artillery spotters, or to attack other infantry or armor. There is also Infantry support which includes heavier weapons such as bazookas.

Name: Fish Or Cut Bait
Description:
This is a game about a fishing competition. Players toss a die to move around the board as they attempt to land on the best fishing holes. Randomly drawn fish cards indicate the weight of the trophy fish. Cards are kept secret from the other players during the competition. Players must also head for the bait shop in order to keep fishing. The game ends after a player reaches the dock... points are scored for the weight of each trophy fish and the player with the most points is declared the winner.

Includes the board, six tokens, fish cards, bait markers, a die, and the rules.

Name: The Game of French History
Description: 72 Cards. Each one summarises an event in the life of a French King. Players must fill in the blanks. Answers supplied in an accompanying booklet.
